channel.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India
channel.description: World News: TOI brings the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Donald Trump said he would go to Venezuela if he loses to Kamala but...
item.description: In his interview with Elon Musk, Trump said he would go to Venezuela if he loses the election. “If something happens with this election, which would be a horror show, we’ll meet the next time in Venezuela,” Trump said. It was a swipe at Kamala Harris as Trump said Venezuela with is in the middle of a political crisis over the re-election of Nicholas Maduro will be a far safer place than the US if Kamala Harris becomes the president.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Atlanta joins Bengal in 'Reclaim the night' protest against Kolkata's RG Kar rape-murder horror
item.description: The social media call to women to come out on the streets at night to reclaim their space in protest against the rape-murder horror of Kolkata's RG Kar Medical Hospital reached far beyond Bengal as the Bengalis in Atlanta have decided to join the protest seeking justice for RG Kar incident. The protest will be near Global Mall from 6.30 ET onwards, one of the organizers informed. The protest will not be held under any banner -- just a spontaneous coming together of the Bengalis in Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ukraine's unexpected advance into Russian territory: How the events unfolded
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Disgusting': British influencer slammed for putting underwear between breads in supermarket
item.description: A video of a woman taking off her underwear and then keeping it amid breads at a supermarket has drawn flak and disgust of social media. According to reports, the woman in the viral challenge video was Chole Lopez, an English influencer, who claimed to have done this bizarre act on camera as part of a challenge.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Harris campaign editing news headlines in her favour within Google search ads: Report
item.description: Kamala Harris' campaign was editing news headlines in Google ads to create a favorable image without news websites' consent. Google stated the ads did not breach policies, although a technical glitch made some ads appear lack disclosures. Brands like CNN, USA Today, and NPR were unaware their links were used this way.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Frightening': New Zealand charity unknowingly distributes meth-laced candy
item.description: A New Zealand charity inadvertently handed out candies laced with lethal amounts of methamphetamine, leaving three individuals ill. Authorities are investigating the incident, highlighting the complex methods of drug importation. The New Zealand Drug Foundation revealed that each candy contained 3 grams of methamphetamine, making them extremely dangerous.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Watch: Barron Trump's friend is asked why Gen Z would vote for Donald. His 20-second reply is...
item.description: Barron Trump's influencer friend Bo Loudon who is working for Trump campaign said 'rightful president' Donald Trump did not run America like other presidents, but like a businessman. He made it thrive like his other businesses and Gen Z would vote him for economic security, Bo Loudon said on Fox News.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Nikki Haley says Trump must stop whining about Kamala Harris: 'Talking about her race, dumbness...'
item.description: Former GOP presidential hopeful Nikki Haley said Donald Trump and the Republicans should stop whining about Kamala Harris succeeding Joe Biden's contest as they anticipated it pretty well. In an interview with the Fox News, Nikki launched an attack on Kamala Harris and said there's no need for an interview of her; as she can be taken at her word when she says illegal immigrants should be able to vote and be given driver's licenses.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Judge rejects Donald Trump’s recusal plea for third time in hush money case
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Donald Trump explains his slurring, lisping in interview with Musk: 'Strange'
item.description: Former president Donald Trump took to Truth Social after he was heard lisping and slurring in the X interview with Elon Musk and acknowledged that he sounded strange. But it was not owing to any medical reason, the GOP presidential candidate said adding that it was because of the "complexity of modern day equipment, and cellphone technology".
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hong Kong activist gets three days in jail in prison complaint form case
item.description: A Hong Kong court sentenced pro-democracy activist Owen Chow to three days in jail for giving an unauthorised document to his solicitor, Phyllis Woo, who was fined HK$1,800. Chow, already serving a five-year term, faces potential life imprisonment on separate charges. He intends to appeal the new conviction and sentence.

item.title: German military base sealed off due to suspected sabotage, security source says
item.description: A German military base near Cologne airport was sealed off due to suspected sabotage. Authorities advised 4,300 soldiers and 1,200 civilian employees not to drink tap water over contamination fears. The base houses the fleet used by Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his ministers. Investigations are ongoing with no immediate suspects identified.

item.title: Turkey, Iraq to hold new round of security talks in Ankara, source says
item.description: Senior Turkish and Iraqi officials met in Ankara to discuss cooperation on security issues, as relations improved following Turkish President Erdogan's visit to Baghdad. Iraq labelled the PKK a banned organization. Talks aim to institutionalize agreements and evaluate further initiatives, with Turkey's cross-border operations set to continue until terrorism is eradicated.

item.title: More than 1,000 arrested following UK riots, police say
item.description: British authorities arrested over 1,000 people following days of rioting sparked by misinformation about the killings of three girls in Southport. The unrest, involving violence, arson, and racist attacks, spread across England and Northern Ireland. Swift judicial actions led to many being jailed. The National Police Chiefs' Council reported 1,024 arrests and 575 charges across the UK.

item.title: Two South Korean missionaries kidnapped in northern Kenya
item.description: Gunmen kidnapped two South Korean missionaries in northern Kenya near the Ethiopian border. The abduction occurred in the village of Odda, and their phone was last traced to the border. National police and local officials are involved in the investigation. In a separate incident, eight Kenyans were shot dead west of Moyale, and their bodies were burned.

item.title: Why New Zealand citizens are leaving the country in record numbers?
item.description: Government statistics revealed a record number of New Zealanders left the country due to rising unemployment and weak economic growth. In the year ending June 2024, 131,200 departures were recorded, with 75% moving to Australia. The central bank reduced interest rates to 5.25% as inflation neared its target range, indicating economic challenges for New Zealand.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Why did Japan's PM Kishida resign: A visionary step or compulsion?
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced he will not seek re-election in the September LDP leadership vote. Kishida's popularity had dipped due to corruption scandals, affecting public trust. Speculation is rising about potential successors, including Toshimitsu Motegi and Taro Kono, who will be elected as the new prime minister.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: UK woman killed husband, hid body for 18 years before dying uncaught
item.description: In November 2015, the skeletal remains of John Sabine were found wrapped in plastic in Beddau, Wales. His wife, Leigh Ann Sabine, who died in October 2015, was believed to have killed him 18 years earlier. She concealed his body and continued to collect his pension until her death. The case was revealed posthumously.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: High doses of meth found in candy distributed by New Zealand charity
item.description: A New Zealand charity distributed food parcels containing candies filled with lethal amounts of methamphetamine. Approximately three grams of methamphetamine were found in the candies. The distributed parcels affected eight families, though no hospitalizations were reported. The police have launched a criminal investigation, and the charity is contacting up to 400 people to retrieve the contaminated parcels.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ilhan Omar wins primary race in Minnesota
item.description: Ilhan Omar secured her primary win in Minnesota's 5th District against Don Samuels with a 56.2%-42.9% lead. Omar, part of the progressive 'Squad,' emphasized themes of housing and healthcare rights in her victory speech. Fundraising played a crucial role, with Omar raising $6.2 million compared to Samuels' $1.4 million. Omar will now face Republican Dalia Al-Aqidi.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
